Three Hopkins students were
injured, one seriously, when a
van they and another student
were riding in collided with
several trees after swerving off
Goodnow Drive in front of the
MSE Library shortly before
4:30 a.m. on Saturday, March
15, according to campus security's report of the incident.
Junior Class President
Christopher Verica was taken
to the Shock Trauma Center of
the University of Maryland
Hospital and was listed as in
"critical but stable" condition
on the day of the accident, the
report stated. The report added that William J. Dwyer, a
senior, was "taken to Union
Memorial Hospital, treated for
forehead lacerations and released," and David Hayward, also
a senior, was taken to Union
Memorial and "treated for
lacerations of the left knee and
face." He had not been released at the time of the report, but
told the News-L,etter this week
that he is fully recovered.

•The sale oT two new T-shirts
has been announced as part of
a fund-raising effort by the
council. In an effort to make
the HOP Coffee Houses profitable, the activity has been
renamed Hopkins Cafe and TShirts resembling those of the
Hard Rock Cafe will be sold at
the next Cafe on May 5. HOP
Director Andy Chun explained
that while the Coffee Houses
have been extremely popular in
the past, limited seasting does
not generate enough revenue to

cover the costs of the acts.
Student Service Committee
Co-chairs Stephanie Weissman
and Dave Shade also requested
a $450 loan to order new
Hopkins Lacrosse T-Shirts.
When asked whether profits
will benefit the SSC or the entire council, Weissman replied,
"Our committee is council."
The expected $100 profit will go
to the general SC budget.
The council also agreed on a
design for new Student Council T-Shirts, which President
Paul Kadri will make council
members more visible to their
constituents. The shirts will
read "STUD CO" on the front,
while "ENT UNCIL" will appear on the reverse. This design
was chosen over a simple "Student Council" and the catchy
"Kad's Kids."
Council members volunteered to pay for the shirts
themselves, instead of subsidizing them with council funds.
Since the academic year is

almost over and the council is
running on a tight budget, it
was reasoned that using the students' money for the shirts
would be inappropriate.
•Education
Committee
Chairman Mark Komisky
reported to council on the findings of the Committee on
Undergraduate Studies in
regards to the course evaluation
procedure at Hopkins. "The
system should be improved, but
by keeping the present Course
Guide, not eliminating it,"
Komisky said.
"The Course Guide is the
most viable system at present,"
Komisky said and added that
the CUS recommended funds
for enlarging the staff and
bringing additional administrative support to the
publication.
Methods to improve collection and distribution of the
evaluation forms were determined to be the most needed
change. After studying pro-

cedures in use at numerous colleges, the CUS stated that a
standardized form dealing with
course content should be
distributed along with a departmental form which would concentrate on the professor and
the quality of teaching.
Student representatives of
the Course Guide should be
allowed to use class time to administer the evaluations and
collect them immediately afterwards, instead of asking
students to return the forms at
a later date. This would greatly increase the number of
respondents and improve the
validity of the results, according to Komisky.
*Chairman Dave Shade announced that the Student
Health Advisory Committee
will be conducting a survey,
which was recommended by
Dean of Administration Robert
Welch and will evaluate student
perceptions of Health Services.

In response to a proposal introduced to council by
Secretary Rachel Cohen on
March 12, the council decided
to draft a letter which will be
sent to prominent South
African government leaders on
behalf of Thozamile Gqweta,
who has been declared a
"prisoner of conscience" by
Amnesty International.
Gqweta, a prominent black
trade unionist in South Africa
and member of the United
Democratic Front, is currently
on trial on charges of high
treason. He and 15 other officials of the UDF were arrested
on February 21, 1985, after
non-violent campaigns to
dismantle the apartheid system.
As a show of support, the
council will send a letter to
President Pieter Botha and the
Ministers of Justice and Law
and Order asking that the
charges against Gqweta be
dropped.
While the original proposal •
had included sending a request
to the Board of Trustees for
similar support, council
members felt that it was not
their place to do so. "This is
very different from the Naidu
proposal," commented Senior
Class President Paul Donio. "I
don't see the rationale for asking the Board."
The council decided instead
to notify the Board of Trustees
of its action in this matter,
without requesting additional
support. The council approved
the proposal by a vote of
15-1-2.
Also at the council meeting:
•Senior Class Representative
Alison Little announced that
plans have been finalized for
this year's Homewood Lecture,
which will be held on Sunday,
April 20, at 8 p.m. in the Garrett Room. Ruth Aranow of the
Chemistry Department will present a lecture entitled "That
Makes Sense!" The discussion
will center around "how we
learn and why sometimes things
make sense and sometimes they

don't," explained Little.
"This is the way the council
can recognize an outstanding
professor," added Little, "and
we are very happy to have Dr.
Aranow as our featured
speaker."

GALA to Host Gay
Student Conference
by Frank Wu
The Gay and Lesbian
Alliance will host the First Annual Baltimore Area Gay and
Lesbian Students Conference
this Saturday, an event which
Alliance Chairman Joshua
Stuart calls "very ambitious."
Two noted Baltimore gay activists, Mardie Walker and
Walter Harper, are featured
speakers.
The Conference is designed
to "draw people from different
campuses," according to
Stuart. As this is the first such
gathering, Stuart said the
Alliance is not certain how it
will turn out. "We'll know
when we get there,"he said.
The first portion of the conference will be a discussion between students leading groups at
the various Baltimore area colleges. Stuart noted that many
of these schools lack formal
organizations for gay students.
According to Stuart, this
meeting is a result of "interest
in getting the different campuses together
to do
something," and might help the
development of gay groups at
other schools.
A general assembly at 8:00
p.m. in the L/V Room,open to
all interested students and
faculty will follow. Walker,
president of the local chapter of
the Gay and
Lesbian
Democratic Club, and Harper,
a leader in the effort to pass gay
rights legislation in the city, will
speak about gay issues. Stuart
explained these speakers will
discuss "grassroots efforts;
this-is-going-on-in-Baltimore
sort of thing."

Stuart said "the preprofessional attitude which pervades Hopkins weighs in a lot
of gay people's minds....If they
come out as gay, they're afraid
they won't get a good internship." He named "strong fears
about the future" as one of the
main problems for gay
students.
Stuart also mentioned that
the administration's dealings
with the Alliance has been "fair
positive treatment," with "no
problems...no
arbitrary
silliness."
Stuart said that in the past,
the Alliance has thrown parties
as its main social funtion. He
added, "that's not to say we're
a group of people who throw
parties all of the time...direct
outreach is our first concern."
He continued, "this will be an
event to get together as an
organized function."

Kandel to Deliver
Morning Address
by Ethan Rarick
Eric Kandel, a neuroscientist
from Columbia University, will
be the speaker at this year's
morning
commencement
ceremony, according to University President Steven Muller.
The morning ceremony is
organized by the administration, which also selects the
speaker. Roger Revelle, an
oceanographer, will speak at
the afternoon ceremony, which
is organized by students. (See
story, page 1.)
Kandel will probably speak
on science, but his speech will
not be overly technical, Muller
said in a wide-ranging interview
March 27.
"Just what the families of
the graduates want to hear,"
Muller said of Kandel's topic.

'Stun Gun' Sales to Women
Rise on University Campuses
(CPS)—Increasing numbers
of women on the Ohio State
campus reportedly are arming
themselves with weapons called
"stun guns" to defend
themselves.
And despite some uncertain-'
ty over the safety of the
weapons—which are about the
size of calculators and fire electric currents of up to 50,000
volts—women on other campuses also are carrying them.
In fact, college women are
expressing an increasing interest
in stun guns, reports Greg
Pollack, a salesman for Nova
Technologies, which manufactures the devices.
Although Nova, based in
Austin, Texas, has no specific
demographic data about who is
buying its guns, the return of
warranty slips indicates a trend
toward student interest in the
devices, which sell for $70 to
$90.
Nova has been manufacturing its stun gun for about three
years, and has sold about
175,000, Pollack notes.
To use one, a person presses

a button. A test arc of electricity is then visible from the two
rods that stick out from the
gun.
"The test arc is frequently an
adequate deterrent," Pollack
maintains, adding "electricity,
by its very nature, is ominous."
If the arc does not scare an
assailant, then the user touches
the attacker, giving him a twoto-five second zap.
Pollack says that the XR
5000—Nova's main gun
model— is safe in that its current will not stun the user.
Furthermore, research at the
Universities of Wisconsin and
Nebraska prove Nova's gun
will not permanently hurt the
victim, Pollack says.
Although California's state
government allows teachers and
school staffers to carry stun
guns at schools, some college
officials don't like them.
At Grossmont Community
College in El Cajon, Ca., where
a student sold about 20 of the
stun weapons about two years
ago, students now are banned
from toting the weapons.

"We certainly don't recommend students to carry them,"
says Dan Keller, executive
director of Campus Crime
Prevention Programs in
Louisville, Ky.
If people are not trained to
handle weapons, they can get
hurt, Keller maintains. "Policing is best left up to law enforcement officials." •
Feminists also have varying
opinions on whether women
should carry stun guns.
"Anything that can make
women feel safer, that's okay
with me, but it is not our program's first choice," contends
Linda Markle of the Women's
Services Center at Ohio State.
The center provides courses in
self defense.
However, a user "is buying
into the patriarchal-capitalist
system. You are paying for the
privilege of your freedom,"
Markle maintains.
Bernice Sandler, director of
the Project on the Education
and Status of Women in
Washington, D.C., carries a
knife and Mace.

A Lax Poll
Well, what is going on around here?
The lacrosse team is tied forfourth and
fifth in the most recent poll? Absolutely
unheard of. Next thing you know premeds really will be well-rounded.
After all, good ol' John Hopkin simply isn't—ever— ranked that low. We
could take second, maybe even third.
Fourth place alone might be palatable,
but a tie with—of all people—Navy?
Yuck!
So how did this horrid situation come
about? Well, it seems the fine gentlemen
who vote in the poll wanted to stick it
(sorry) to Hopkins. How else does one
explain the oddities in this week's voting?
• For example, the Midshipmen are the
equals of the Blue Jays? Nonsense.
Granted their record is 7-0, but their
schedule has been, at best, mediocre.
They have beaten some good (not great)
teams—Penn, UMBC and Rutgers come
to mind—but they have yet to play a truly first-rate club.(That will change Saturday when they take on Army.)
Another case of mysterious voting:
Maryland, by beating North Carolina,
jumps clear over Syracuse and Hopkins.
The Tar Heels were, of course, number
one and undefeated. And they were playing at home, where they are notoriously
tough to beat. Still, they were the first
good team Maryland has played. (The
Terrapins' first five games were jokes
against the likes of Boston College and
Ohio Wesleyan.) They surely haven't
proven themselves to be the best team in
the country.

So herewith, our own (rational) poll:
1) Syracuse. 2) Hopkins. 3) Maryland.
4) Carolina. The Orangemen clearly
deserved to be number one after last
week. They were number two going into the weekend, whipped a respectable
team (Adelphi, 19-9) and number one
lost. They have also beaten the Blue
Jays, the team that was number three.
Speaking of the Jays, they should have
been number two, having lost only to
Syracuse and having beaten a good team
(Virginia) with a clutch fourth quarter
goal (Dressel to Wood on a beauty) on
Saturday. The Terps are a legitimate
number three (they're undefeated and
did, after all, beat Carolina), and the Tar
Heels certainly shouldn't drop below number four.
The real problem is that should the
Jays—pardon the obscenity—lose to
Carolina on Saturday (a real possibility),
they would be dangerously close to losing the home-field advantage for the
quarter-finals. Can you imagine?—not
a single play-off game at Homewood.
The world would stop.
The solution to all this is obvious.
Everybody should go to the game Saturday (since it's the first home contest since
March 8 y'all ought to be ready for
lacrosse), and be even louder than
normal.
Oh and one last thing—far too few of
you took our advice at the Syracuse game
to turn around, wave frantically and yell
"Hi, Stevie!" So come on, guys. This is
your last chance.

Spanking the HOP
Mary Ellen Porter seems to be getting
into the maternal spirit—she's learning
to spank her own child. No, silly, we
don't mean the actual kid, we mean the
HOP.
Well, okay, the HOP may not exactly
be Porter's creature, but she is on its
board, and it is at least as much an arm
of the administration as of the Student
Council. So when Porter suspended the
HOP for alcohol violations the other
day, it was far different than suspending
a frat.
To review a bit, the HOP was barred
for one month from serving alcohol at
its functions. Since all campus social
events must now be coordinated through
the HOP, that actually means that
alcohol won't be served at any campus
event. Furthermore, two IDs will be required at future events from everyone
who wants to purchase alcohol.
The thing that makes all of this a littie strange (and in some ways heartening) is that the HOP is in part an administration body. Both Porter and
Director of Residential Life Andrea
Perry serve on its Board. While that may
not seem like much at first glance, it is
far more significant a role for the administration than existed under the
HOP's predecessor, the Social
Committee.

Indeed, that was one of the rationales
behind the HOP's founding. It was
created, the old fogies will remember,
almost two years ago. At the time, incoming Student Council President Jon
Lana (along with a lot of other people)
thought the social programming structure for the campus needed an overhaul.
The result was the HOP, which swallowed up a couple of smaller committees and
took on the role of master schedulemaker for Homewood.
It operated informally for about half
year,
and then was offered (over, oddly
a
enough, Porter's strong objections) to
the student body for approval in a
referendum. It passed overwhelmingly (it
was hardly the most controversial vote
in the history of the school), and the
HOP was officially born.
So a fair number of people were more
than a little surprised when Porter
suspended the HOP. Actually, though,
it's sort of refreshing. At least occasionally, it seems, the administration can
act fairly impartially, in this case almost
suspending a part of itself. Indeed, the
event for which the HOP got in trouble
was a dance played by the Crusty
Nostrils, a group that includes. . .Porter.
Still, considering the administration's
track record, this is a surprising (and
pleasant) case of fairness.

Moliere was far from being
a conservative seventeenth century playwright. When his
fourth successful play The
School for Wives, opened in
1662, a rage of controversy ensued in the literary circles of
Paris that would move provincial critics to go so far as to
stage The Critique of The
School of Wives. Undaunted,
however (perhaps because of
strong support from the French
king, Louis VIV), Moliere continued to assault the pretentious

Doherty Resigns As Blue Jay Hoop Coach
Courtesy of Athletic Center
Johns Hopkins University
Athletic Director Robert Scott
announced that Ed Doherty has
resigned his position as head
basketball coach.
Doherty, affectionately
known by players and colleagues as "Nappy," had joined
the the Hopkins athletic staff as
Interim Coach in 1981. His
teams won 43 games and lost 71
during his five year stint. He
also served as coach of the
track and field squad.
"I have been in basketball
for more than 25 years," said
Doherty. "I have enjoyed the
game very much, but 25 years
is a long time and I just feel it

r

is time to get away from the day
to day strain of today's intercollegiate sports.
"I've enjoyed being at
Hopkins," he continued, "and
enjoyed working with Bob
Scott and all the coaches here.
And I especially will miss the
relationships with the fine
young men who were members
of my squads. But I feel it is
just time to try my hand at
other things."
Doherty's career included 1::
years as coach at Loyola College where his teams had 164
wins against 153 losses. He also
served as coach of Baltimore's
professional team in the Continental League in 1979 until the

franchise folded. As a player at
Loyola College, he was captain
of a squad that won the MasonDixon tournament in his senior
year and he was chosen for AllState and All-Conference
honors. Two years ago he was
tapped for the Loyola College
Hall of Fame.
Athletic Director Scott expressed strong regret about

Doherty's resignation. "We
were lucky to have had Nap on
our staff," Scott said, "and our
students have strongly benefitted from their associations with
him. In these days when college
athletics come under fire in
some quarters, he has consistently displayed high
character, strong ethical beliefs,
and traditional moral values."

Coach Doherty's basketball
career at Hopkins ended on a
high note when the Blue Jays
closed the season with a stunning 83-79 upset of Washington
College, ranked eleventh in the
national Division Ill polls.
Doherty's Jays also surprised
with a 67-66 win over Middle
Atlantic Conference champion,
Franklin and Marshall.

'Stun Gun' Sales to Women
Rise on University Campuses
(CPS)—Increasing numbers
of women on the Ohio State
campus reportedly are arming
themselves with weapons called
"stun guns" to defend
themselves.
And despite some uncertain-'
ty over the safety of the
weapons—which are about the
size of calculators and fire electric currents of up to 50,000
volts—women on other campuses also are carrying them.
In fact, college women are
expressing an increasing interest
in stun guns, reports Greg
Pollack, a salesman for Nova
Technologies, which manufactures the devices.
Although Nova, based in
Austin, Texas, has no specific
demographic data about who is
buying its guns, the return of
warranty slips indicates a trend
toward student interest in the
devices, which sell for $70 to
$90.
Nova has been manufacturing its stun gun for about three
years, and has sold about
175,000, Pollack notes.
To use one, a person presses

a button. A test arc of electricity is then visible from the two
rods that stick out from the
gun.
"The test arc is frequently an
adequate deterrent," Pollack
maintains, adding "electricity,
by its very nature, is ominous."
If the arc does not scare an
assailant, then the user touches
the attacker, giving him a twoto-five second zap.
Pollack says that the XR
5000—Nova's main gun
model— is safe in that its current will not stun the user.
Furthermore, research at the
Universities of Wisconsin and
Nebraska prove Nova's gun
will not permanently hurt the
victim, Pollack says.
Although California's state
government allows teachers and
school staffers to carry stun
guns at schools, some college
officials don't like them.
At Grossmont Community
College in El Cajon, Ca., where
a student sold about 20 of the
stun weapons about two years
ago, students now are banned
from toting the weapons.

"We certainly don't recommend students to carry them,"
says Dan Keller, executive
director of Campus Crime
Prevention Programs in
Louisville, Ky.
If people are not trained to
handle weapons, they can get
hurt, Keller maintains. "Policing is best left up to law enforcement officials." •
Feminists also have varying
opinions on whether women
should carry stun guns.
"Anything that can make
women feel safer, that's okay
with me, but it is not our program's first choice," contends
Linda Markle of the Women's
Services Center at Ohio State.
The center provides courses in
self defense.
However, a user "is buying
into the patriarchal-capitalist
system. You are paying for the
privilege of your freedom,"
Markle maintains.
Bernice Sandler, director of
the Project on the Education
and Status of Women in
Washington, D.C., carries a
knife and Mace.

A Lax Poll
Well, what is going on around here?
The lacrosse team is tied forfourth and
fifth in the most recent poll? Absolutely
unheard of. Next thing you know premeds really will be well-rounded.
After all, good ol' John Hopkin simply isn't—ever— ranked that low. We
could take second, maybe even third.
Fourth place alone might be palatable,
but a tie with—of all people—Navy?
Yuck!
So how did this horrid situation come
about? Well, it seems the fine gentlemen
who vote in the poll wanted to stick it
(sorry) to Hopkins. How else does one
explain the oddities in this week's voting?
• For example, the Midshipmen are the
equals of the Blue Jays? Nonsense.
Granted their record is 7-0, but their
schedule has been, at best, mediocre.
They have beaten some good (not great)
teams—Penn, UMBC and Rutgers come
to mind—but they have yet to play a truly first-rate club.(That will change Saturday when they take on Army.)
Another case of mysterious voting:
Maryland, by beating North Carolina,
jumps clear over Syracuse and Hopkins.
The Tar Heels were, of course, number
one and undefeated. And they were playing at home, where they are notoriously
tough to beat. Still, they were the first
good team Maryland has played. (The
Terrapins' first five games were jokes
against the likes of Boston College and
Ohio Wesleyan.) They surely haven't
proven themselves to be the best team in
the country.

So herewith, our own (rational) poll:
1) Syracuse. 2) Hopkins. 3) Maryland.
4) Carolina. The Orangemen clearly
deserved to be number one after last
week. They were number two going into the weekend, whipped a respectable
team (Adelphi, 19-9) and number one
lost. They have also beaten the Blue
Jays, the team that was number three.
Speaking of the Jays, they should have
been number two, having lost only to
Syracuse and having beaten a good team
(Virginia) with a clutch fourth quarter
goal (Dressel to Wood on a beauty) on
Saturday. The Terps are a legitimate
number three (they're undefeated and
did, after all, beat Carolina), and the Tar
Heels certainly shouldn't drop below number four.
The real problem is that should the
Jays—pardon the obscenity—lose to
Carolina on Saturday (a real possibility),
they would be dangerously close to losing the home-field advantage for the
quarter-finals. Can you imagine?—not
a single play-off game at Homewood.
The world would stop.
The solution to all this is obvious.
Everybody should go to the game Saturday (since it's the first home contest since
March 8 y'all ought to be ready for
lacrosse), and be even louder than
normal.
Oh and one last thing—far too few of
you took our advice at the Syracuse game
to turn around, wave frantically and yell
"Hi, Stevie!" So come on, guys. This is
your last chance.

Spanking the HOP
Mary Ellen Porter seems to be getting
into the maternal spirit—she's learning
to spank her own child. No, silly, we
don't mean the actual kid, we mean the
HOP.
Well, okay, the HOP may not exactly
be Porter's creature, but she is on its
board, and it is at least as much an arm
of the administration as of the Student
Council. So when Porter suspended the
HOP for alcohol violations the other
day, it was far different than suspending
a frat.
To review a bit, the HOP was barred
for one month from serving alcohol at
its functions. Since all campus social
events must now be coordinated through
the HOP, that actually means that
alcohol won't be served at any campus
event. Furthermore, two IDs will be required at future events from everyone
who wants to purchase alcohol.
The thing that makes all of this a littie strange (and in some ways heartening) is that the HOP is in part an administration body. Both Porter and
Director of Residential Life Andrea
Perry serve on its Board. While that may
not seem like much at first glance, it is
far more significant a role for the administration than existed under the
HOP's predecessor, the Social
Committee.

Indeed, that was one of the rationales
behind the HOP's founding. It was
created, the old fogies will remember,
almost two years ago. At the time, incoming Student Council President Jon
Lana (along with a lot of other people)
thought the social programming structure for the campus needed an overhaul.
The result was the HOP, which swallowed up a couple of smaller committees and
took on the role of master schedulemaker for Homewood.
It operated informally for about half
year,
and then was offered (over, oddly
a
enough, Porter's strong objections) to
the student body for approval in a
referendum. It passed overwhelmingly (it
was hardly the most controversial vote
in the history of the school), and the
HOP was officially born.
So a fair number of people were more
than a little surprised when Porter
suspended the HOP. Actually, though,
it's sort of refreshing. At least occasionally, it seems, the administration can
act fairly impartially, in this case almost
suspending a part of itself. Indeed, the
event for which the HOP got in trouble
was a dance played by the Crusty
Nostrils, a group that includes. . .Porter.
Still, considering the administration's
track record, this is a surprising (and
pleasant) case of fairness.

Azrael was heiress to her
father's cotton fortune, and her
mother was a prominent Jewish
charity worker and socialite.
The Azraels set up residence

and both continued writing until Louis Azrael died. In 1982,

family and friends gave $25,000
to the Writing Seminars.

interest on the sum ‘vill provide

Doherty Resigns As Blue Jay Hoop Coach
Courtesy of Athletic Center
Johns Hopkins University
Athletic Director Robert Scott
announced that Ed Doherty has
resigned his position as head
basketball coach.
Doherty, affectionately
known by players and colleagues as "Nappy," had joined
the the Hopkins athletic staff as
Interim Coach in 1981. His
teams won 43 games and lost 71
during his five year stint. He
also served as coach of the
track and field squad.
"I have been in basketball
for more than 25 years," said
Doherty. "I have enjoyed the
game very much, but 25 years
is a long time and I just feel it

r

is time to get away from the day
to day strain of today's intercollegiate sports.
"I've enjoyed being at
Hopkins," he continued, "and
enjoyed working with Bob
Scott and all the coaches here.
And I especially will miss the
relationships with the fine
young men who were members
of my squads. But I feel it is
just time to try my hand at
other things."
Doherty's career included 1::
years as coach at Loyola College where his teams had 164
wins against 153 losses. He also
served as coach of Baltimore's
professional team in the Continental League in 1979 until the

franchise folded. As a player at
Loyola College, he was captain
of a squad that won the MasonDixon tournament in his senior
year and he was chosen for AllState and All-Conference
honors. Two years ago he was
tapped for the Loyola College
Hall of Fame.
Athletic Director Scott expressed strong regret about

Doherty's resignation. "We
were lucky to have had Nap on
our staff," Scott said, "and our
students have strongly benefitted from their associations with
him. In these days when college
athletics come under fire in
some quarters, he has consistently displayed high
character, strong ethical beliefs,
and traditional moral values."

Coach Doherty's basketball
career at Hopkins ended on a
high note when the Blue Jays
closed the season with a stunning 83-79 upset of Washington
College, ranked eleventh in the
national Division Ill polls.
Doherty's Jays also surprised
with a 67-66 win over Middle
Atlantic Conference champion,
Franklin and Marshall.
